subtopics.name: 1.1 Particles in the atom and atomic radius
details: understand that atoms are mostly empty space with a small, dense, positively charged nucleus
identify and describe protons, neutrons and electrons in terms of relative charge and relative mass
understand the terms atomic (proton) number and mass (nucleon) number
describe the distribution of mass and charge within an atom
describe the behavior of beams of protons, neutrons and electrons in electric fields
determine the numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons present in both atoms and ions
state and explain the trends in atomic radius and ionic radius across a period and down a group

subtopics.name: 1.2 Isotopes
details: define the term isotope
understand the notation xKy for isotopes
explain why isotopes of the same element have the same chemical properties
explain why isotopes of the same element have different physical properties (limited to mass and density)

subtopics.name: 1.3 Electrons, energy levels and atomic orbitals
details: understand the terms shell, sub-shell and orbital
describe the number of orbitals that make up s, p and d sub-shells and the number of electrons that can fill s, p and d sub-shells
describe the shapes of s and p orbitals
state the electronic configuration of atoms and ions for the elements hydrogen to krypton
explain the electronic configurations in terms of energy of the electrons and inter-electron repulsion
use the electrons-in-boxes notation

subtopics.name: 1.4 Ionisation energy
details: define the term first ionisation energy
construct equations to represent first, second and subsequent ionisation energies
identify and explain the trends in ionisation energies across a period and down a group
explain the trends in ionisation energy in terms of nuclear charge, atomic/ionic radius, shielding and spin-pair repulsion

subtopics.name: 2.1 Relative masses of atoms and molecules
details: define the unified atomic mass unit
define relative atomic mass, Ar, relative molecular mass, Mr, and relative formula mass

subtopics.name: 2.2 The mole and the Avogadro constant
details: define and use the term mole in terms of the Avogadro constant

subtopics.name: 2.3 Formulae
details: write formulae of ionic compounds from ionic charges
construct balanced chemical equations (including state symbols)
construct ionic equations from chemical equations
define and use the terms empirical formula and molecular formula
understand the terms anhydrous, hydrated and water of crystallisation

subtopics.name: 2.4 Reacting masses and volumes (of solutions and gases)
details: perform calculations involving reacting masses
perform calculations involving volumes of gases (using the molar gas volume)
perform calculations involving concentrations and volumes of solutions
calculate percentage yield and percentage purity
identify the limiting reagent in a reaction

subtopics.name: 3.1 Electronegativity and bonding
details: define electronegativity
explain the factors influencing electronegativity and the trends across a period and down a group
use electronegativity values to predict the type of bonding (ionic or covalent)

subtopics.name: 3.2 Ionic bonding
details: describe ionic bonding as the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
describe the giant ionic lattice structures of sodium chloride and magnesium oxide

subtopics.name: 3.3 Metallic bonding
details: describe metallic bonding as the electrostatic attraction between positive metal ions and a sea of delocalised electrons

subtopics.name: 3.4 Covalent bonding and coordinate bonding
details: define covalent bonding and coordinate (dative covalent) bonding
describe sigma (σ) and pi (π) bonds
explain hybridisation (sp, sp2, sp3)
use bond energy and bond length values to compare the reactivity of covalent bonds

subtopics.name: 3.5 Shapes of molecules
details: state and explain the shapes of molecules and ions using VSEPR theory
predict bond angles in molecules and ions

subtopics.name: 3.6 Intermolecular forces
details: describe hydrogen bonding
explain the concept of bond polarity and permanent dipoles
describe van der Waals' forces (instantaneous dipole – induced dipole and permanent dipole – permanent dipole)

subtopics.name: 3.7 Dot-and-cross diagrams
details: draw dot-and-cross diagrams to represent the bonding in ionic and covalent compounds

subtopics.name: 4.1 The gaseous state
details: explain the origin of pressure in a gas
state the basic assumptions of the kinetic theory of ideal gases
use the ideal gas equation pV = nRT

subtopics.name: 4.2 Bonding and structure
details: describe the lattice structures of crystalline solids: giant ionic, simple molecular, giant molecular and giant metallic
relate the physical properties of a substance to its structure and bonding

subtopics.name: 5.1 Enthalpy change, ΔH
details: understand that chemical reactions are accompanied by energy changes (exothermic and endothermic)
construct and interpret reaction pathway diagrams
define standard enthalpy changes of reaction, formation, combustion and neutralisation
calculate enthalpy changes from experimental results using q = mcΔT

subtopics.name: 5.2 Hess’s Law
details: apply Hess’s Law to construct energy cycles
calculate enthalpy changes using bond energies or enthalpy cycles

subtopics.name: 6.1 Redox processes
details: calculate oxidation numbers of elements in compounds and ions
describe and explain redox processes in terms of electron transfer and changes in oxidation number
identify oxidising and reducing agents

subtopics.name: 7.1 Chemical equilibria
details: explain the terms reversible reaction and dynamic equilibrium
state Le Chatelier’s principle and apply it to deduce the qualitative effects of changes in temperature, pressure or concentration
deduce expressions for equilibrium constants Kc and Kp
calculate values of Kc and Kp from experimental data

subtopics.name: 7.2 Brønsted–Lowry theory of acids and bases
details: describe acids and bases in terms of proton transfer
identify conjugate acid-base pairs
define the terms strong acid, weak acid, strong base and weak base
define pH and calculate pH values for strong acids and strong bases

subtopics.name: 8.1 Rate of reaction
details: explain the term rate of reaction
explain, in terms of the collision theory, the effect of concentration and pressure changes on the rate of a reaction
calculate the rate of a reaction from a tangent to a graph of concentration vs time

subtopics.name: 8.2 Effect of temperature on reaction rates
details: define activation energy, EA
sketch and use the Boltzmann distribution to explain the effect of temperature on the rate of a reaction

subtopics.name: 8.3 Catalysts
details: explain that catalysts lower the activation energy by providing an alternative reaction pathway
describe the mode of action of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts

subtopics.name: 9.1 Periodicity of physical properties
details: describe and explain the variations in atomic radius, ionic radius, melting point and electrical conductivity for elements in Period 3

subtopics.name: 9.2 Periodicity of chemical properties
details: describe the reactions of Period 3 elements with oxygen, chlorine and water
describe the reactions of the oxides and chlorides of Period 3 elements with water
explain the acid/base behaviour of the oxides and hydroxides of Period 3 elements

subtopics.name: 9.3 Chemical periodicity of other elements
details: predict the properties of elements and their compounds given information about their position in the Periodic Table

subtopics.name: 10.1 Similarities and trends in properties
details: describe the reactions of Group 2 elements with oxygen, water and dilute acids
describe the thermal decomposition of Group 2 nitrates and carbonates
state the trends in solubility of Group 2 hydroxides and sulfates

subtopics.name: 11.1 Physical properties of Group 17
details: describe the trends in colour, volatility and state at room temperature for Group 17 elements

subtopics.name: 11.2 Chemical properties of halogens and hydrogen halides
details: describe the relative reactivity of the halogens as oxidising agents
describe the relative thermal stability of the hydrogen halides

subtopics.name: 11.3 Reactions of halide ions
details: describe the relative reactivity of halide ions as reducing agents
describe the reactions of halide ions with silver nitrate followed by ammonia

subtopics.name: 11.4 Reactions of chlorine
details: describe the reaction of chlorine with cold and hot aqueous sodium hydroxide (disproportionation)
explain the use of chlorine in water purification

subtopics.name: 12.1 Nitrogen and sulfur
details: explain the lack of reactivity of nitrogen gas
explain the basicity of ammonia
describe the formation of atmospheric oxides of nitrogen and sulfur and their role in acid rain formation

topics.name: 13. Introduction to AS Level organic chemistry

subtopics.name: 13.1 Formulae, functional groups and naming
details: interpret and use the general, structural, displayed and skeletal formulae of the classes of organic compounds
apply IUPAC nomenclature to aliphatic organic compounds

subtopics.name: 13.2 Characteristic organic reactions
details: define the terms homolytic and heterolytic fission, free radical, initiation, propagation, termination, nucleophile, electrophile, addition, substitution, elimination, hydrolysis, condensation, oxidation and reduction
describe reaction mechanisms using curly arrows

subtopics.name: 13.3 Isomerism
details: describe structural isomerism (chain, position, functional group)
describe stereoisomerism: geometrical (cis/trans) and optical (chiral centres)

subtopics.name: 14.1 Alkanes
details: describe the unreactivity of alkanes (non-polar bonds)
describe the complete and incomplete combustion of alkanes
describe the free-radical substitution of alkanes by chlorine and bromine

subtopics.name: 14.2 Alkenes
details: describe the electrophilic addition reactions of alkenes with hydrogen, steam, hydrogen halides and halogens
describe the oxidation of alkenes with cold, dilute KMnO4 and hot, concentrated KMnO4
describe addition polymerisation

subtopics.name: 15.1 Halogenoalkanes
details: classify halogenoalkanes as primary, secondary or tertiary
describe the nucleophilic substitution reactions of halogenoalkanes (SN1 and SN2 mechanisms)
describe the elimination reactions of halogenoalkanes

subtopics.name: 16.1 Alcohols
details: classify alcohols as primary, secondary or tertiary
describe the combustion of alcohols
describe the substitution reactions to form halogenoalkanes
describe the reaction with sodium
describe the oxidation of alcohols
describe the dehydration of alcohols to form alkenes
describe the formation of esters

subtopics.name: 17.1 Aldehydes and ketones
details: describe the oxidation of aldehydes
describe the reduction of aldehydes and ketones
describe the nucleophilic addition of HCN to aldehydes and ketones
describe the reaction with 2,4-DNPH and the iodoform test

subtopics.name: 18.1 Carboxylic acids
details: describe the formation of carboxylic acids from alcohols, aldehydes and nitriles
describe the reactions of carboxylic acids with metals, alkalis, carbonates and alcohols

subtopics.name: 18.2 Esters
details: describe the acid and base hydrolysis of esters

subtopics.name: 19.1 Primary amines
details: describe the formation of primary amines from halogenoalkanes and nitriles

subtopics.name: 19.2 Nitriles and hydroxynitriles
details: describe the formation of nitriles from halogenoalkanes
describe the formation of hydroxynitriles from aldehydes and ketones
describe the hydrolysis of nitriles

subtopics.name: 20.1 Addition polymerisation
details: identify the repeat unit of an addition polymer
identify the monomer(s) present in a given section of an addition polymer
recognise the difficulty of the disposal of poly(alkenes)

subtopics.name: 21.1 Organic synthesis
details: deduce reaction pathways given the starting materials and the product
identify the functional groups present in a molecule

subtopics.name: 22.1 Infrared spectroscopy
details: analyse an infrared spectrum to identify the functional groups present in a molecule

subtopics.name: 22.2 Mass spectrometry
details: analyse mass spectra to identify the molecular ion peak and deduce the relative molecular mass
deduce the number of carbon atoms in a compound using the M+1 peak
identify fragmentation peaks

topics.name: 13. Introduction to AS Level organic chemistry

subtopics.name: 13.1 Formulae, functional groups and naming
details: interpret and use the general, structural, displayed and skeletal formulae of the classes of organic compounds
apply IUPAC nomenclature to aliphatic organic compounds

subtopics.name: 13.2 Characteristic organic reactions
details: define the terms homolytic and heterolytic fission, free radical, initiation, propagation, termination, nucleophile, electrophile, addition, substitution, elimination, hydrolysis, condensation, oxidation and reduction
describe reaction mechanisms using curly arrows

subtopics.name: 13.3 Isomerism
details: describe structural isomerism (chain, position, functional group)
describe stereoisomerism: geometrical (cis/trans) and optical (chiral centres)

subtopics.name: 14.1 Alkanes
details: describe the unreactivity of alkanes (non-polar bonds)
describe the complete and incomplete combustion of alkanes
describe the free-radical substitution of alkanes by chlorine and bromine

subtopics.name: 14.2 Alkenes
details: describe the electrophilic addition reactions of alkenes with hydrogen, steam, hydrogen halides and halogens
describe the oxidation of alkenes with cold, dilute KMnO4 and hot, concentrated KMnO4
describe addition polymerisation

subtopics.name: 15.1 Halogenoalkanes
details: classify halogenoalkanes as primary, secondary or tertiary
describe the nucleophilic substitution reactions of halogenoalkanes (SN1 and SN2 mechanisms)
describe the elimination reactions of halogenoalkanes

subtopics.name: 16.1 Alcohols
details: classify alcohols as primary, secondary or tertiary
describe the combustion of alcohols
describe the substitution reactions to form halogenoalkanes
describe the reaction with sodium
describe the oxidation of alcohols
describe the dehydration of alcohols to form alkenes
describe the formation of esters

subtopics.name: 17.1 Aldehydes and ketones
details: describe the oxidation of aldehydes
describe the reduction of aldehydes and ketones
describe the nucleophilic addition of HCN to aldehydes and ketones
describe the reaction with 2,4-DNPH and the iodoform test

subtopics.name: 18.1 Carboxylic acids
details: describe the formation of carboxylic acids from alcohols, aldehydes and nitriles
describe the reactions of carboxylic acids with metals, alkalis, carbonates and alcohols

subtopics.name: 18.2 Esters
details: describe the acid and base hydrolysis of esters

subtopics.name: 19.1 Primary amines
details: describe the formation of primary amines from halogenoalkanes and nitriles

subtopics.name: 19.2 Nitriles and hydroxynitriles
details: describe the formation of nitriles from halogenoalkanes
describe the formation of hydroxynitriles from aldehydes and ketones
describe the hydrolysis of nitriles

subtopics.name: 20.1 Addition polymerisation
details: identify the repeat unit of an addition polymer
identify the monomer(s) present in a given section of an addition polymer
recognise the difficulty of the disposal of poly(alkenes)

subtopics.name: 21.1 Organic synthesis
details: deduce reaction pathways given the starting materials and the product
identify the functional groups present in a molecule

subtopics.name: 22.1 Infrared spectroscopy
details: analyse an infrared spectrum to identify the functional groups present in a molecule

subtopics.name: 22.2 Mass spectrometry
details: analyse mass spectra to identify the molecular ion peak and deduce the relative molecular mass
deduce the number of carbon atoms in a compound using the M+1 peak
identify fragmentation peaks

subtopics.name: 23.1 Lattice energy and Born-Haber cycles
details: define lattice energy, enthalpy change of atomisation and electron affinity
construct and use Born-Haber cycles to calculate lattice energy or other enthalpy changes
explain the effect of ionic charge and ionic radius on the numerical magnitude of lattice energy

subtopics.name: 23.2 Enthalpies of solution and hydration
details: define enthalpy change of solution and enthalpy change of hydration
use energy cycles involving enthalpy change of solution, lattice energy and enthalpy change of hydration
explain the effect of ionic charge and ionic radius on the numerical magnitude of enthalpy change of hydration

subtopics.name: 23.3 Entropy change, ΔS
details: define the term entropy
predict the sign of the entropy change for a given reaction
calculate standard entropy changes from standard entropy values

subtopics.name: 23.4 Gibbs free energy change, ΔG
details: use the Gibbs equation ΔG = ΔH - TΔS
predict the feasibility of a reaction using ΔG

subtopics.name: 24.1 Electrolysis
details: predict the identity of the substances liberated during electrolysis
calculate the quantity of charge passed during electrolysis
calculate the mass and/or volume of substance liberated during electrolysis

subtopics.name: 24.2 Standard electrode potentials
details: define standard electrode potential, Eθ, and standard cell potential, Eθcell
describe the standard hydrogen electrode
use standard electrode potentials to calculate standard cell potentials
use the Nernst equation to predict the effect of concentration on electrode potential
use the relationship ΔG = -nEθcellF

subtopics.name: 25.1 Acids and bases
details: calculate the pH of strong acids, strong bases, weak acids and buffer solutions
define and use the solubility product, Ksp
explain the common ion effect

subtopics.name: 25.2 Partition coefficients
details: define and use the partition coefficient, Kpc

subtopics.name: 26.1 Rate equations
details: explain and use the terms rate equation, order of reaction, rate constant, half-life, rate-determining step
construct and use rate equations
deduce the order of a reaction from experimental data
suggest a multi-step mechanism for a reaction

subtopics.name: 26.2 Catalysis
details: describe the mode of action of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts
explain the effect of a catalyst on the rate constant

subtopics.name: 27.1 Trends in properties
details: explain the trends in thermal stability of Group 2 carbonates and nitrates in terms of ionic radius and charge density
explain the trends in solubility of Group 2 hydroxides and sulfates in terms of lattice energy and enthalpy change of hydration

subtopics.name: 28.1 General properties
details: define a transition element in terms of d-block electrons
explain why transition elements have variable oxidation states, behave as catalysts, form complex ions and form coloured compounds

subtopics.name: 28.2 Ligands and complex formation
details: define the term ligand
describe the geometry of transition metal complexes (linear, octahedral, tetrahedral, square planar)
describe ligand exchange reactions

subtopics.name: 28.3 Colour of complexes
details: explain the splitting of d-orbitals in transition metal complexes
explain the colour of transition metal complexes in terms of the absorption of light

subtopics.name: 28.4 Stereoisomerism
details: describe and illustrate stereoisomerism in transition metal complexes (geometrical and optical)

subtopics.name: 28.5 Stability constants
details: define and use the stability constant, Kstab, of a complex ion

topics.name: 29. Introduction to A Level organic chemistry

subtopics.name: 29.1 Formulae, functional groups and naming
details: apply IUPAC nomenclature to aromatic and cyclic compounds

subtopics.name: 29.2 Characteristic organic reactions
details: describe the mechanism of electrophilic substitution in arenes
describe the mechanism of addition-elimination reactions

subtopics.name: 29.3 Shapes of aromatic organic molecules
details: describe the structure of benzene in terms of a delocalised pi system
explain the stability of benzene compared to alkenes

subtopics.name: 29.4 Isomerism: optical
details: understand the terms optical activity, racemic mixture and chiral catalyst
describe the importance of chirality in drug synthesis

subtopics.name: 30.1 Arenes
details: describe the electrophilic substitution reactions of benzene and methylbenzene (nitration, halogenation, Friedel-Crafts alkylation and acylation)
explain the directing effects of substituents on the benzene ring

subtopics.name: 31.1 Halogen compounds
details: describe the formation of halogenoarenes
compare the reactivity of halogenoarenes with halogenoalkanes

subtopics.name: 32.1 Alcohols
details: describe the reaction of alcohols with acyl chlorides to form esters

subtopics.name: 32.2 Phenol
details: describe the acidity of phenol
describe the reactions of phenol with bases, sodium, diazonium salts, nitric acid and bromine

subtopics.name: 33.1 Carboxylic acids
details: describe the formation of carboxylic acids from nitriles, amides and esters
compare the relative acidity of carboxylic acids, phenol, alcohols and water

subtopics.name: 33.2 Esters
details: describe the formation of esters from acyl chlorides and phenols

subtopics.name: 33.3 Acyl chlorides
details: describe the formation of acyl chlorides from carboxylic acids
describe the hydrolysis of acyl chlorides
describe the reactions of acyl chlorides with alcohols, phenols, ammonia and primary amines

subtopics.name: 34.1 Primary and secondary amines
details: describe the formation of amines from amides and nitrobenzene
compare the basicity of amines

subtopics.name: 34.2 Phenylamine and azo compounds
details: describe the formation of phenylamine
describe the reaction of phenylamine with nitrous acid to form diazonium salts
describe the coupling reactions of diazonium salts to form azo dyes

subtopics.name: 34.3 Amides
details: describe the formation of amides from acyl chlorides
describe the hydrolysis of amides
explain the relative lack of basicity of amides

subtopics.name: 34.4 Amino acids
details: describe the acid/base properties of amino acids and the formation of zwitterions
describe the formation of peptide bonds

subtopics.name: 35.1 Condensation polymerisation
details: describe the formation of polyesters and polyamides
identify the monomers used to form a given condensation polymer

subtopics.name: 35.2 Predicting type of polymerisation
details: predict whether a given monomer will undergo addition or condensation polymerisation

subtopics.name: 35.3 Degradable polymers
details: explain why condensation polymers are generally biodegradable whereas addition polymers are not

subtopics.name: 36.1 Organic synthesis
details: design multi-step synthetic routes for organic molecules
explain the use of protecting groups (knowledge of specific protecting groups is not required)

subtopics.name: 37.1 Thin-layer chromatography
details: interpret chromatograms and calculate Rf values

subtopics.name: 37.2 Gas / liquid chromatography
details: interpret gas/liquid chromatograms in terms of retention times and percentage composition

subtopics.name: 37.3 Carbon-13 NMR spectroscopy
details: analyse Carbon-13 NMR spectra to determine the number of carbon environments
predict the number of peaks in a Carbon-13 NMR spectrum

subtopics.name: 37.4 Proton (1H) NMR spectroscopy
details: analyse Proton NMR spectra to determine the number of proton environments and their relative numbers
interpret splitting patterns using the n+1 rule
identify the chemical shift values for protons in different environments using the Data Booklet
